Tyson Refrigerated Processed Meats, Portwall - Houston
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary            

I. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

It is the policy of Tyson Foods Inc to implement a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68. Included in this process is the implementation of OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.119.

The purpose of implementing these programs is to prevent the release of anhydrous ammonia. By doing so we protect employees and guests on site while protecting the general public off site. 

As part of these programs, Tyson Foods has developed an emergency response plan that includes a well trained response team that coordinates closely with local fire department and other off site emergency personnel.

II. The stationary source and regulated substance

Tyson Refrigerated Processed Meats, Portwall is a food manufacuring facility located in a heavey industrial section of Houston Texas. 

The food production process at this facility requires very low temperatures to process and maintain the finished product. The refrigeration system uses anhydrous ammonia to provide the proper temperature in the production areas, coolers and blast freezers. 

III. General accident release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention.

A. Tyson Refrigerated Processed Meats, Portwall Facility  has designed and implemented a preventative maintenance program to reduce the potential for release of ammonia from the refrigerations system. This program complies with the requirements of OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management. The key concept of this release prevention program is employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment and appropriate training of all Tyson Team Members.

The PSM Team is responsible for conducting and implementing findings from the PHA Process Hazard Analysis for the ammonia system. Team members are also members of the facility emergency response team. This ER

Team has developed an Emergency Response Plan which includes specific procedures and equipment to allow the safe response to an ammonia leak or release. These procedures are designed to minimize a leak or release.

The list below identifies individuals with specific responsibilities in the prevention and response plans.

B. Lines of Authority and Responsibility in RMP

Dick Stoffregen: Plant Manager 

The Plant Manager has responsible for all regulatory affairs within the plant.  Dick delegates program responsibilities to individuals in the facility depending on individual roles and job descriptions.  

Travis Schulte:  Complex Environmental Manager

The Complex Environmental Mgr. is responsible for oversight of all environmental programs including the Risk Management Program.  However, the day-to-day management of the PSM and RMP program is the duty of the PSM coordinator.  

Jeff Abercrombie: Maintenance Superintendent

The Maintenance Supt, is responsible for Maintenance, Repair, and Refrigeration systems at the facility.  The Maintenance Superintendent is the direct supervisor of the Refrigeration Supervisor whom the Process Safety and Risk Management Programs have been delegated.  The Maintenance Superintendent is responsible for implementation and maintenance of the Process Safety and Risk Management Prevention Program documentation, including but not limited to Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Training, Operating Procedures, Incident Investigation and Emergency Response.  The Refrigeration Superintendent is responsible for refrigeration staff and all refrigeration operations, maintenance of refrigeration equipment. The Refrigeration Manager ensures all equipment in the refrigeration system is maintained in proper working order.

Refrigeration Operator Staff:

The Refrigeration staff act in a supporting role for Process Safety and Risk Management and as operators of the refrigeration system.  Day-to-day operations include but are not limited to perf

orming operational checks on refrigeration equipment, completion and maintenance of equipment logs, preventive maintenance, pre-operational inspections.  

Joe Ray Cepeda: Plant Safety Manager

The Plant Safety Manager is responsible for development and implementation of safety policies and procedures at the plant site.  The Plant Safety Manager shall work side by side with the Refrigeration Supervisor to ensure all refrigeration staff are provided with proper personal protective equipment and enforcement that it is worn when appropriate.  This position is also responsible for Contractor Safety program, Hot Work permits and updates to the emergency response program.  The Plant Safety Mgr. also supports the hazmat team to ensure all personnel and equipment remain fully functional and available at all times for emergency response.  

IV. Five-year accident history

There have not been any releases of anhydrous ammonia at this facility in the last five years that resuted in deaths, injuries, or significant damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.    

V. Emergency Response Program

As part of these programs, Tyson Foods has developed an emergency response plan that includes a well-trained response team that coordinates closely with local fire department and other off site emergency personnel.

VI. Planned changes to improve safety

The site has been and plans to continue to send Managers & Refrigeration Team Members to outside training on PSM/RMP and refrigeration technical training.
